question.title: Logs of Spring Boot Docker service not accessible from Spring Boot Admin
question.body:
I have a Spring Boot service dockerized and it registers well with Spring Boot admin. Property logging.file.name is specified in a Git repository that after service startup is retrieved from the config server. My dockerized service bind the docker log path to a volume.

Accessing the logging > logfile page from spring boot admin didn'tt displays anything. I updated my docker-compose.yml file of my service with logging file name property, the value I specified in it is the path to the volume bound to the service:

environment:
  - SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod
  - SPRING_CLOUD_CONFIG_URI=http://config-service:9999
  - LOGGING_FILE_NAME=/opt/microservices/logs/$${spring.application.name}.log

Now when accessing the logging > logfile page I'm able to view the first logs line but nothing more, it stops at the log of properties retrieved from the config server:

2025-06-26T11:50:03.131+02:00  INFO 1 --- [organisation-service] [restartedMain] b.c.PropertySourceBootstrapConfiguration : Located property source:
    [BootstrapPropertySource {name='bootstrapProperties-configClient'},
     BootstrapPropertySource {name='bootstrapProperties-vault:project-service/prod'},
     BootstrapPropertySource {name='bootstrapProperties-https://gitlab.dns.fr/project/config-repo.git/project-service/project-service-prod.yml';},
     BootstrapPropertySource {name='bootstrapProperties-https://gitlab.dns.fr/project/config-repo.git/project-service/project-service.yml';},
     BootstrapPropertySource {name='bootstrapProperties-https://gitlab.dns.fr/project/config-repo.git/application.yml';}]

I tried to change the logger level, nothing worked. I viewed my log file in the volume and it holds other entries. Any Idea how to resolve the issue?

answers.body:
Your logs aren't appearing because Docker doesn't write logs to a file by default - everything goes to stdout/stderr. Spring Boot Admin is looking for a log file that is not there.

Quick fix - add this to your application.yml

logging:
  file:
    name: /tmp/app.log

management:
  endpoints:
    web:
      exposure:
        include: "*"  # or specifically include 'logfile'

This will tell Spring Boot to actually write to a file, not just to the console. The /tmp directory is fine for testing.

Make sure your Spring Boot Admin can reach your service's actuator endpoints. In docker networks, use the service name, not localhost:

spring:
  boot:
    admin:
      client:
        url: http://admin-server:8080
        instance:
          service-base-url: http://your-service-name:8080  # Use Docker service name

If you see logs there, but not in Admin UI, then it is a network issue between the services.

Honestly, though, for Docker setups, I just use docker logs container-name or docker-compose logs -f service-name. Spring Boot Admin's log viewer is pretty clunky for containerized apps. If you really want centralized logging, check out ELK or Loki instead.
